titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. At ten this morning I went with Mr: Smith to the Roman Catholic Church and heard the funeral service of Mr: Colombi performed. The Church was well filled, but not crowded— Most of the foreign Ministers were there, and generally in full or half-uniform— Some of them however were in frock dresses, and all wore pelisses— The Church was excessively cold— The service lasted nearly two hours. The Coffin was placed in the Centre of the Church, and surrounded with three rows of large wax tapers which were lighted.— The hat and sword of the deceased were laid upon the Coffin— The service was a Mass, and the requiem was sung by the quire of boys belonging to the Church, accompanied by the Organ— After the ceremony was over the Coffin was carried out of the Church placed upon a herse, and followed by a procession of Carriages taken to the place of interment— We did not go to the procession but returned home— Mr: Harris afterwards called upon me; he saw Count Romanzoff yesterday, who received him with great distinction, and in the midst of his levee bowed round to all the stars and ribbands, and took him into his Cabinet; where he had with him a Conversation of an hour.— This Evening I wrote a page of short hand; but with some difficulty— I could not read.

2. I received this morning from Mr: Lohman the Courrier de Londres, from 23. Feby: to 5. March. It is a French Gazette published in London. I found it in it, some further accounts from America, and particularly a correspondence between the Secretary of State and Genl: Turreau, in which the subject of the Consular Certificates of Origin is introduced.— Mr: Lohman requested me to return the papers this morning, so that I had not more than an hour to read them— As I usually make it the business of a day when I go out in the morning I endeavour to pay a number of visits at once. Just as I was going out, Mr Tilden called upon me; Mr: Lynch and he are going to Gothenburg, and thence if they can to England and to the United States— I promised to apply for Courier’s Passports for them when they should be ready to go, and desired to be informed some days before hand, when they should fix the day for their departure— I paid a visit first to the French Ambassador who received me— I found him in the midst of a room full of Orlowsky’s pictures, which he has packed up to send to Paris— He told me that Count Lauriston his successor was to leave Paris the 20th: of March, and that he expected him here in about ten days. He promised to send me a copy of the Petition from the merchants here for the admission of vessels with licences to be granted by this Government, and which the Emperor had refused— He also told me that the Emperor would dine this day with the Empress mother at Gatschina, and return this Evening to St: Petersburg.— I went from the Ambassador’s to Mr: Grammann’s house and left the papers for Mr: Lohman—then called at Count St: Julien’s and left Cards for him and for Mr: Lebzeltern— Then went to Mr: Meyer’s on the island; where I bespoke a draft upon Amsterdam; and then went and pass’d an hour at Count Stedingk’s; with whom I had much conversation upon a variety of topics.—Mr: & Mrs: Merry—Mr: Foster—the Count’s own affairs; in which he said he had within a fortnight made an unpleasant discovery—the probable failure of a house to which he had entrusted in deposit half a million of rubles— He gave me several copies of the late Swedish Ordinance respecting the admission and residence of foreigners in that Country; and he engaged me to come and dine with him, and to bring Mrs: Adams with me next Sunday.— After leaving him I took my usual walk and on passing by the Winter-Palace, saw the Imperial banner flying, as a signal that the Emperor was in the City— He arrived therefore before the time announced by the Ambassador— Mr: Plummer pass’d the Evening with us—the Ladies at Madame Colombi’s.

3. Long visits from Mr: Montréal and Mr: Harris, with the former of whom I had much conversation respecting the order for the purchase of goods which Mr: Gray has sent here— He also mentioned to me that the Ambassador was desirous of obtaining information concerning the state of commercial affairs here before his departure— But that he was much misinformed and very ignorant upon the subject— And as to Lesseps; he had sent samples of Hemp in a letter to the Minister of Marine at Paris.— Mr: Harris mentioned to me that Mr: Borel, Count Romanzoff’s private Secretary had told him in Confidence that Count Pahlen, would be authorized to leave the United States, and go to Brazil if he thought proper, and then that Borel had again asked him why Mr: Adams did not propose the negotiation of a Treaty—hinted that the favourable opportunity was passing away; and extolled to him the terms which Mr: Navarro had obtained for the Brazil trade— As it happens however, I know precisely the issue of Navarro’s Negotiation; for he has communicated the whole of it to me himself— And I think I now understand the motive of Mr: Borel’s anxiety for a Treaty between the United States and Russia— Mr: Montreal mentioned that there were also some suggestions on foot of a Treaty of Commerce between France and Russia.— Mr: Bridge, who has lately returned from Reval pass’d two hours with us this Evening.

4. Mr: Raimbert called upon me this morning, and we had some further conversation respecting Mr: Gray’s order for goods— It was this morning also that I had the conversation with Mr: Harris, mentioned as of yesterday— Mr: Raimbert told me the Ambassador had bespoke at considerable expence statements of all the Russian trade throughout the Empire— In my walk this day upon the Quay, I found preparations making for an illumination at the Ambassador’s, from which it appeared that he had received information of the delivery of the Empress of France— Mr: Smith dined abroad, and was informed that she had a son, born on the 20th: of March— In the Evening I paid a visit at Madame Colombi’s; but she was in the Bath— I went to Madame de Betancourt’s and found her and her two daughters at home. Mr: Everett was there. I saw the illuminations at the Ambassador’s, at General Pardo’s and at Count Bussche’s houses.

5. Morning visit from Mr: Preuss, a native of Dantzick but now a Citizen of the United States, and an inhabitant of Alexandria— He came last Summer from America, and had a packet of Newspapers for me which he forwarded from Königsberg— In my walk this day I met Mr: Navarro, who said to me Eh bien! voila un Roi de Rome qui vient au monde, donnant des coups de pied— Comme si nous n’en avions pas déja assez— Messrs: Smith, Everett and Gray all dined abroad, and Mr: Harris dined with us. General Betancourt his Lady and two daughters spent part of the Evening with us— The General gave me some information concerning the school which he is establishing here, which is properly a school for Engineers— They have now forty pupils from 15 to 18 years old and four teachers; three of whom are Frenchmen, and one a Russian— The objects of instruction are Mathematics—Geometry—Drawing, and Architecture. It is formed on the model as an imitation in Miniature of the Ecole Polytechnique at Paris— This he says was one of the good Institutions which sprung out of the worst period of the French Revolution— It was a sort of Asylum suggested by some men of Science; for a refuge from the popular fury to which they found themselves exposed. The term of Instruction is for two years, the scholars are taken from 15 to 16 years of age. 150 every year, and for which five or six hundred candidates present themselves— They select only the best informed— They are required to study ten hours every day, and if a pupil absents himself three days together he is excluded from the school. After coming out they have to go through two years more at the school for the Marine, for the Bridges & High ways, or Fortifications according to their several destinations—and on issuing from these schools, the young men are immediately appointed officers in the army, or Navy. I enquired of the General what was the instruction given here at the school of the Cadets— Very little more he said than reading and writing; and for many of them hardly that— It is impossible in this Country to make either the teachers or the pupils labour—they must be idle— He requires at his school that the pupils should understand French, because he could get neither teachers nor Books that were Russian— The Books that they study are by Bossu— Monge and La Croixwith a translated Russian Work

6. Mr: Montréal called upon me this morning, and I gave him a certificate for the bills to be drawn upon the house of Messrs: Bainbridge and Brown in London, for Account of Mr: Gray of Boston— Reading some English Newspapers to 5. March sent me by Mr: Krehmer— It left me time only to write part of a letter to Mr: Gray— The practice of leaving a letter unfinished from one day to another is a bad one— I wrote short hand (of which I am already sick) in the Evening; and finished it at Cards.

7. Palm-Sunday. At 10 in the morning I went to the Roman Catholic Church, and heard Mass performed— The Church was crowded. The only part of the Ceremony which I had not seen before was the distribution of the holy palm-branches— But while the mass was performing, there were in the Confessionals on each side of the altar in the left wing of the Church a Priest who confess’d a number of the people, men and women as they successively presented themselves. The Confessional is in the form of a sentry box, open at the upper part and with a low door reaching about 2 1/2 feet from the floor to let the Confessor in and out— It is barely large enough to hold one person, has a bench to set down upon, and a small lattice window on each side at which the penitent kneeling on the outside applies his lips while the Priest listens to it from within— Each confession lasted from five to ten minutes— The Priest applied himself alternately to the lattice on each side and muffled himself up entirely in his Cloak— When the confession was finished he threw aside the Cloak from his face, locked his fingers together and holding his hands up thus joined, with his eyes cast upwards muttered a short prayer— Then separating his hands with the right one cross’d his own breast and with the knuckles of the two first fingers gave two gentle knocks at the side of the lattice where the penitent was kneeling, as the signal of absolution. The persons who went to confession were of the lower Classes of the People— Common Soldiers— footmen in livery and women of apparently the like rank— I observed their countenances on going to and returning from Confession— They were generally and evidently anxious as they approached and joyous or at least relieved as they retired from the box— Some of them before Confession kneeled and prayed with great apparent earnestness on the steps of the altar.— There was a young woman whose confession told itself in her shape— Her previous earnest anxiousness was greater, her confession longer, and her subsequent satisfaction less unmingled than was discernible in any of the other cases. Some of them after confessing went and received the Communion— After the mass was finished I walked untill 2. O’Clock— At 4. I went with the Ladies and dined at Count Stedingk’s. There were about fifteen persons of the Company several of whom I did not know. Only one Lady besides ours. A Madame Davidoff with her husband and his brother— She is of a French emigrant family, daughter of the Duke de Grammont and Grand daughter of the Duke de Guiche— General Watzdorf, General Driessen and Mr: Labensky were there. The Count shewed me the German London newspaper to the 15th: of March which came by the Swedish Post.— We came home early—the Ladies pass’d the Evening at Mrs: Krehmer’s— I read Massillon’s Discourses on the Jubilee—to Children on their receiving Confirmation, and to the Nuns of a Convent in his diocese, who had fallen into dissensions— Also several of his Pastoral-Letters, or Mandemens. These are all short Discourses in which I found not much to remark— The 9th. and 10th. Sections of Robinson’s Character of Christ pursue the analysis of the Sermon on the mount.

8. Mr: Borel, the private Secretary of Count Romanzoff called upon me this morning, and shewed me a Paris Moniteur of 20 March, containing a Speech of the Emperor Napoleon to the Deputies of the Cities of Hamburg, Lubeck and Bremen— It relates to the Berlin and Milan decrees, and is little more than an Amplification of the Note in the Moniteur of 2. March— He told me that Count Romanzoff had requested him to call on me and shew me this paper, as it would be interesting to me— Mr: Harris was with me an hour or two and mentioned that he had received letters from America of 30. January— Mr: Lohman brought me the Courier de Londres, to the 15th. of March, which he could only allow me to look over and return to him while he was with me, he was obliged immediately to return them. These visits engrossed the whole morning so that it was with difficulty that I finished a letter to Mr: Gray, begun the day before yesterday.— Finished the Evening at Cards.

9. Mr: Montreal was with me this morning and gave me information of the further proceedings of the house in the Execution of Mr: Gray’s orders— The morning was so rainy that I could not go out untill within half an hour of dinner time— I added therefore a second walk of about an hour after dinner—the first time this Season— And for the future the length of the day will allow an Evening’s walk, of which I propose to avail myself— Dr: Galloway was here to see Mrs: Adams who is quite unwell— On returning from my walk we closed the Evening with Cards— I wrote this day a letter to my brother, and it was the occupation of the day— My short-hand writing fails; I hope not irredeemably— Mr: Krehmer sent me some English Newspapers (Courier’s) to the 15th: of March— They contain accounts from America to the 12th: of February.— The only way that I get any News from America is through the English News-papers.

10. Mrs: Adams was ill great part of the Night; and this morning she was bled, by Mr: Gibbs, a Surgeon sent here by Dr: Galloway. The Doctor himself also called. I was employed the whole morning in reading English Newspapers— I met in one of the French Gazettes not long since an ingenious parallel between the Erudition of the 17th: and that of the 19th: century; with an argument in favour of the latter— The writer has justly considered the acquisitions of modern languages and the acquaintance with their literature as contributing to balance the classical superiority of the former period; but he has not taken into account the reading of newspapers and periodical Journals, which then did not exist, and which are now so prodigiously multiplied.— They employ upon an average at least two hours of every day in my life, and certainly have done so for the last twenty years.— Mr: Montreal was here this morning, and brought me a minute of the drafts yesterday, on Account of Mr: Gray— Mr: Harris was also with me, and shewed me a letter which he had written to the Minister of Finance Mr: Gourieff concerning the bonds required to be given in the cases of the American vessels which have been most recently admitted. I had understood Baron Campenhausen, that a simple engagement of the importers would be received without requiring bonds of the consignees; for producing the Consular Certificates which are wanting, within a year— It appears however that Bonds are required— Mr: Harris’s letter is very warm; and he was quite indignant at the proceeding of Baron Campenhausen— He thinks too the order to the Custom-house at Reval ambiguous, and the Bonds required in terms which may entrap the consignees— I approved of his letter so far as it required an explanation of any equivocal expressions; and as it might induce the Emperor to order that no Bonds should be required— But I considered this as a matter concerning the consignees more than the importers— We had a Company of Americans to dinner— Messrs: Harris, Fisher, Lynch, Tilden, Smith, Cunningham, Baer, Lawler, Plummer, Preuss, Bridge, and Woodward.— Evening at Cards.

11. Mr: R. Smith came this morning, and requested me to inspect and certify his Passport from the Department of State, which I did— He is going for Archangel to-morrow.— I had no other interruption in the course of this day, and began a letter to the Secy: of State. Walk’d before dinner on the river Quay to the Fontanka, and after dinner to the end of the Galeerenhof— Read about an hour in the first volume of Tooke’s view of Russia— I have a physical difficulty of writing which continually grows upon me and for which I believe there is no remedy.

12. Good Friday; which is this year the same in both the Calendars— I accompanied Catherine Johnson to the Roman Catholic Church, where we saw the performances of the day. We went before 10. in the morning, but the ceremonies had commenced at 9. The Church was crowded, and it was with difficulty that Catherine, and Martha, whom she took with her found seats— I stood the whole time— Besides the Mass there is a procession and representation of a sort of religious pantomime, exhibiting the Death and burial of Christ. A crucifix with a figure of Christ is carried round, under a canopy, laid out on Cushions in the Chancel, and then transported in solemn procession into a chapel to the left of the great Altar.— In this Chapel there is a scenical representation of the Sepulchre, with a remote view of Mount Calvary upon which stand the three Crosses—and of the Temple of Jerusalem— There is a transparent Coffin with the image of a dead body within it, large as human figures, and painted images, of the two Maries on one side of the Coffin, and two Angels on the other— The figures of two Roman Soldiers appear as guards at the entrance of the Sepulchre, which is lighted by sepulchral lamps—the small crucifix which had been carried in the procession was laid on cushions upon a table, barr’d off in front of this scene, and there were two large brazen Canisters on the table for the reception of alms— I saw numbers of men and women successively go up to this table, kiss, the feet, the side and the hand of the image on the cross, and then drop a piece of silver in one of the alms-boxes— There was a Sermon upon the Passion, delivered in the German language; by a person who by his pronunciation appeared to be a pole— He spoke the Discourse from memory, but appeared not remarkably fluent. The Style of his Oratory was moderate, and rather cold than vehement— The division was conformable to the french school, and all the Circumstances of the Passion were introduced into it with ease and propriety— The Morning services were finished, between twelve and one O’Clock— After which I walked about an hour; and again nearly as long after dinner— Mr: Harris spent the Evening with us— Mrs: Krehmer sent to our Ladies, Walter Scott’s Lady of the Lake, of which a single copy, sent to Dr: Crichton as a present has reached this City— I read to the Ladies the first Canto; which is written much in the same manner as the lay of the last Minstrel, and Marmion. Mr: Krehmer sent me also the English Newspapers from the 16th: to the 19th: of March.— George’s Birth-day— Charles 3 f. 1/2 i.

13. Mr: Montréal was here this morning, and gave me some information. He told me a curious anecdote of the Comte Regnault de Saint Jean d’Angely, one of the Emperor Napoleon’s Secretaries of State— His wife, with the assistance of a Russian Prince, who had a kindness for her, had prevailed upon her husband to purchase for 18000 livres, on account of its extreme cheapness a diamond necklace, which the jeweller sold for 30,000, but the Russian Prince, unknown to the Count paid the balance of 12000 livres— But the Count some time after finding that the necklace was really worth much more than he had given for it, began to think that he could make a good bargain, and upon enquiry of another jeweller who offered him 30,000 livres for it, took him at his word, and sold the necklace again.— Mr: Preuss called on me, and informed me that he should be ready to go next Monday week; thinking it not advisable to leave the City during the Easter Holidays— Having heard much of the religious ceremony performed at the Imperial chapel on Easter eve, I was desirous of being a witness of it— But as it is a Ceremony to which the foreign Ministers are not invited, I followed the Directions of Mr: Harris who had already attended it two or three times— He called on me about ten in the Evening, and we went together to the Palace, just at eleven. We were however a full half hour too soon; the apartments not being yet lighted— We sat down during that time in the guard room of the Chevalier Gardes, and then went into the Hall next to that of the throne, where the company was assembling.— The Grand Master of the Ceremonies Narishkin soon after came in, and told us that we must fall in with the crowd, after the Imperial family should pass into the Chapel; but the Grand Marshal Count Tolstoi coming into the Hall afterwards, came up to me; said that he was very glad to have met me—that he would take care to get us introduced into the chapel, for that if we should follow the crowd we should not get a place where we could see any thing— He left us and soon after returned, and as the Imperial family were now just ready to go into the chapel he requested Prince Galitzin to accompany us which he did, and introduced us by a side door from the same guard room, where we had first been seated into the chapel, where the Priests and the Quire of singers were all ready; but the Imperial family had not come in.— He placed us at the left side of the chapel close to the iron-railing which parts the chancel from the Church, and exactly where the foreign Ministers are placed when invited to the celebration of a Te Deum— On the other side of it, within the Chancel were the Chancellor, Count Romanzoff, and two or three other Ministers— Prince Galitzin, and Mr: Gourieff who came with us also went in there. General Watzdorf and Count Bose were already in the chapel, and we all stood together— About five minutes after the Emperor, Empress Mother, Grand Dukes Constantine and Nicholas, and the Grand Duchess Ann came in, followed by the whole Court. The crowd was excessive, and if we had been left to follow the Directions of the Grand Master of the Ceremonies Narishkin, we should hardly have got within the chapel— The Empress was not there having lately met with an accident in falling over a trunk, and receiving a hurt in her forehead which confines her to her Apartment. The Grand Duchess Catherine is gone with her husband to meet the Duke of Oldenburg his father— The Grand Duke Michael was also absent— The Emperor and Empress Mother went and stood within the Chancel at the right hand.— A Gun from the fortress, at Midnight had been the signal of their entering the chapel— One of the Priests went and presented to each of them a lighted taper, which they took into their hands; and a lighted taper was in like manner given to every person in the chapel. This custom is observed at almost all the religious Ceremonies of the Greek Church— The Quire of singers then came out from their stations marching two and two in procession, followed by the Priests; then by the Emperor and Empress Mother, and after them by the Grand Dukes and Grand Duchess, and a small number of the Court Lords and Ladies, all with lighted tapers in their hands; the Quire consisting of singers of all ages from boys of eight or nine years old to men of forty, all in a dark red, and laced Imperial uniform dress, sung as they marched a solemn hymn—& minute guns were firing at the same time from the fortress— The procession went in this manner out of the chapel, and round several of the Palace Halls, and then returned into the Chapel in the same order, the Quire continuing all the time their Chant— The Emperor & Imperial family resumed their stands, and a religious ceremony by the Priests began— It was long, and to me altogether unintelligible— The Principal performing Priest was not as I have usually seen at Court the Metropolitan, and Archbishop of St: Petersburg Ambrose; for he was engaged upon a like ceremony at his Monastery of St: Alexander Newsky— It was not even a Bishop; but the Emperor’s Confessor, who as such is entitled to wear the mitre— He performs the service with much less dignity than the Metropolitan, and his voice could scarcely be
heard— During one part of the ceremony, one of the Priests presented to the Emperor two images to kiss, which Count Romanzoff told me were sacred relics procured by the Emperor Paul from Malta— One of them was a picture of the Virgin Mary, said to have been painted by Saint Luke, and the other was a head of St: John— And these, said the Count are all the benefit we have derived from our relations with Malta— Some time after the Priests ranged themselves all in a line, each of them bearing a sacred image— The Emperor went up to them and kiss’d the images and then embraced each of the Priests who bore them— The Empress Mother followed him and went through the same ceremony, only, instead of her embracing the Priests, they all kiss’d her hand— Count Romanzoff told me before, that she would kiss them all on the lips; but observing that she did not, said that it was always thus done heretofore; and that the kissing of the hand was a very late innovation— The Emperor then embraced his Mother; the Grand Duke’s followed, and embraced the Emperor and Empress— The Grand Duchess came next and went through the process.— Then the Chancellor of the Empire, the Grand Chamberlain’s Count Strogonoff, and Narishkin kiss’d the relics and Priests, and the Emperor, & finally the Empresses hand— A promiscuous crowd of Officers followed during more than an hour, going through the same formality, the quire of singers continuing all the time to chant. At the same time all these Noblemen and Officers, as soon as they had finished the operation with the imperial family turned to one another, and such a scene of kissing and embracing ensued as I never saw before— As they passed from one to the other it was a continual motion like a bee-hive— It reminded me of the Descriptions in Ariosto and Wieland of a Sultan and his Court, falling suddenly into a fit of involuntary dancing— Before the embracing commenced the tapers which had been distributed round among the company were put out, and returned to a Servant who went round with a waiter to receive and take them away— After the embracements were concluded a new religious ceremony commenced a Mass, celebrated by the principal Priest, within the Sanctuary, the Doors of which by the Russian rites are opened only upon this occasion. In the course of this performance was introduced what they call the reading the four Gospels to the four winds of Heaven— One of them was read by the principal Priest at the Altar, which is at the east— Three desks were brought and placed fronting the west, North and South— A large folio volume containing one of the Gospels was placed upon each of them— A Priest came and took his stand before each of them, and read about a chapter of each gospel; each priest reading two or three verses at a time; and following one another successively.— The confessor read in so low a tone that his voice could scarcely be heard; but the other read in a very strong base voice, between speaking and chanting, a fashion of reading peculiar to this Church. The ceremony concluded by the principal Priest’s taking the Communion at the Altar; but in which neither the Imperial family, nor any of the other Priests participated— The whole was finished soon after three in the morning— It was about half-past three when I got home. Mr Harris had retired, unwell about an hour before.

14. There was this morning a very splendid parade, and review of forty-thousand men; half of whom it is said are to march off immediately to the frontiers of Poland.— The Emperor sent a horse to General Watzdorf to attend this parade— Mr: Navarro called to see me this morning.— The Day was uncommonly fine for Easter. In walking on the Quay I met and walked with General Pardo, who told me that he considered an immediate War between Russia and France as inevitable— The Duke of Oldenburg, and the commercial system were the causes— He said that as to the complaints and protest of Russia against the seizure of the Duke of Oldenburg’s territories, Napoleon had answered according to his custom par une sottise—that the thing was sanctioned by a Senatus-consult— As if his Senate consulted any thing but by his command— The General said there would soon be a great dispersion of all the Corps Diplomatique; and that he himself he supposed would also be expected to go— But I can tell you, said he, that on account of my own concerns, I shall not go— I shall stay here.— As to Romanzoff, said he; the only thing that still keeps him in, is that Caulaincourt is yet here— When he is gone, Romanzoff will not last a week— I asked who he thought would succeed him— He said there was talk of Panin—but not Markoff, whom the Emperor personally disliked.— Mr: Harris dined with us— He had told me last Evening, while we were sitting in the guard-room, some information which he had recently received concerning the prospect of War, and he now urged the expedient of making a sort of provisional treaty to be finished if the U.S. Government should send powers— He has renewed this subject to me many times— But I think it best to wait for authority to act.— It is true that if Count Romanzoff goes out there will be little chance of doing any thing afterwards— But in that case any provisional arrangement would avail us nothing.— We had this day a succession of Easter-compliments and eggs of all kinds—glass, porcellain, wood, marble and sugar—besides the real eggs— I lost my usual Sunday reading.

15. Mr Montreal called upon me this morning, and gave me some further information from a confidential source respecting the prospect of a War— I had received on Saturday the notice of a Court at Noon this day; and we went in usual form.— The Diplomatic Circle was held about two O’Clock— The Emperor was particular in his attentions to the French Ambassador, and to all the legations particularly connected with France.— All the Imperial family were there excepting the Empress, and her Sister, the Princess Amelia of Baden— The Grand Duchess Catherine, with her husband the Prince of Oldenburg, and his father the Duke were there— They all arrived yesterday.— I told Count Bussche I had heard he had taken Mr: Bergien’s Country Seat again for the ensuing Summer— He said he had neither signed the contract, nor paid the money; and he should wait— He expected not to pass the Summer here, and did not believe Count Lauriston would come here at-all. Baron Blome spoke much in the same style; lamenting the state of affairs which he said was going from bad to worse, and God knew where it would end. I asked Count Stedingk how the king of Sweden’s health was—he said, that by the last Accounts he was better— But that as he had transferred to the Crown-Prince as much of his authority as he could, he would protract as long as he could the reassumption of power— The king had very reluctantly taken upon him the burden of royalty— He was tired of it, and anxiously desirous of withdrawing himself from it— The business was too irksome to him; not only on account of his age, but of his infirmity; for he was more broken than he was old— The Count would have gone on but we were interrupted— I was talking with Mr: Rayneval, when the Grand Master of the Ceremonies came up and said that on Saturday there was a report that Count Lauriston was arrived; and then mentioned who he had heard it from, and how it had turned out to be a mistake— He left us, and I observed to Rayneval that it must have been an April day’s report— Yes said Rayneval, and Mr: Narischkin had the bonhommie to spread it all over the City— The news rung through the Court like a peal, and when the truth came to be known the enquiry was from whom the report came, and it all went back not a little at the expence of Mr: Narishkin— The Grand-Maitre was still so near us that he heard Rayneval name him, and turned again to us to hear the sequel of what Rayneval was saying— I thought he would have been embarrassed; but he instantly adapted his speech to the hearing of the new interlocutor—“and so, said he, it turned out to be an erroneous report.” It was a great inquiry, whether we were to go and write our names at the Palace of the Grand Duchess Catherine, as is customary at the Grand Duke Constantine’s— At first Mr Narishkin said no; it was not necessary— But the inquiry was so often repeated that at last he said yes; it would be very proper. The Emperor asked me, if I had heard from Mr: J. S. Smith— I said I had; that he was gone from Vienna.— He said that he had heard of his arrival there; but not yet of his departure— Baron Mareschal a Secretary to Count St. Julien who has just returned from Vienna, and who was at Court had told me that Mr: Smith had left Vienna.— As soon as the Court, was over; which lasted as usual not more than ten minutes, we went to the marble palace, and wrote our names in the antichamber of the Grand-Duke Constantine. Then we went to the Palace of Annitschkoff; but there was no preparation of pens ink and paper there; and we left Cards with a servant— I paid visits in person to the Chancellor, Count Romanzoff, the Minister of Finances, Gourieff, Count & Countess Litta, the Grand Chamberlain Narishkin, and the Grand Marshal Count Tolstoi, and to the French Ambassador— On returning home it was so late that I soon went to walk; and after dinner walked again.— Remainder of the Evening at home, reading—

16. This morning, a Messenger came from the Grand-Master of Ceremonies, and informed me that the Grand Duchess Catherine had fixed this day at half past one O’Clock afternoon to receive the Corps Diplomatique at her Palace. We accordingly went at the appointed hour— As I was going up the stairs at the Annitschkoff Palace, I met the Emperor coming down; alone— He stopp’d and said he supposed I was come to see his Sister— I said I was going to pay my respects to her Imperial Highness— He asked me if I had seen the house before— I told him I had—that it was very magnificent;— He said the house was now appropriated to its proper use— Untill lately it had been turned into a sort of Magazine.— I found most of the foreign Ministers already assembled there— Several of them came in after us—and among the rest the Ambassador.— When we were all assembled we were introduced into the apartment next to the Bed-chamber; and soon afterwards the Grand-Duchess came in, accompanied by the Prince her husband— The Grand Master of the Ceremonies, Narishkin made the presentations There were with the Grand Duchess in Attendance only the old Princess Volkonsky and Prince Gargarin the Grand Duchesses Equerry. The Circle was held altogether in the same Style as at the Imperial Palace— The Grand-Duchess spoke to the Ambassador and to all the Ministers, and was followed by the Prince, and the Empresses follow the Emperor— She stood much longer, talking to each person, and after going through all the Circle returned again, and resumed a conversation with the Ambassador; after which she and the Prince retired and we all came home— I walked before dinner, and in the Evening.

17. Mr: Lynch and Mr Tilden called upon me this morning, with the information that they were now ready for their departure, and wished for their Passports to go next Monday— Mr: Preuss had determined before them to go the same day, and I had promised to apply for Passports for him— I told these Gentlemen therefore that they must settle it among themselves which should go first and the others must go a week later— They left me to make the arrangement with him— I received a note from Count Romanzoff, informing me that he was about to dispatch a Courier to Paris, who would take any packets I wish to send— I had morning visits from Count Lüxbourg and Mr: Fisher—both here at the same time— Mr: and Madame Lesseps called in the Evening but were not received. I read the last Canto of the Lady of the Lake— Scotch highland Scenery, and Scottish manners and characters of former days, highly coloured and varnished— Resembling the Lay of the last Minstrel, and Marmion in the measure, form of narrative and intermixture of songs and ballads— The tale is interesting; the incidents marvellous and not improbable; the sentiments suited to the personages, and the versification spirited and harmonious though not very nicely correct— The character of Roderick Dhu is the ideal sublime of the chief of a Scottish clan. That of James 5 is historical, and doubtless a flattered likeness— The rest are secondary characters— The notes are entertaining, and vouch authority for many of the most remarkable incidents in the Poem— We all regretted that it was not longer.

18. I have been waiting more than a Month for an opportunity to send dispatches for the Government of the United States, and now there are three occasions which present themselves all at once. And as it usually happens when the moment occurs I find myself very much crowded for time— I had this morning visits in succession, from Messrs. Preuss—Montréal, Harris, Lynch, Tilden and Woodward; and received at the same time a letter from Mr. W. B Adams at London informing me of his arrival there; and one from Mr: Russell at Paris, brought by a Russian Courier, and sent me by Count Romanzoff—it was long and more than half in cypher which takes longer to read than to write— I had a letter to write myself to the President of the United States, chiefly in cypher; which I finished. I made up my packet for Mr: Russell, and sent it late this Evening to Count Romanzoff— Afterwards read the Introduction and first Canto of Marmion to the Ladies— My company and occupations shortened much my morning walk, and entirely deprived me of the other.— I left part of Mr. Russell’s letter for the morning.

19. I finished early this morning the decyphering of Mr: Russell’s letter— After breakfast I called upon Mr: Navarro, and had a long conversation with him— He gave me readily all the information that he had; which I wanted to compare with that which comes from other quarters— Mr Navarro also told me that he was to stand Godfather to-morrow morning at half past ten O’Clock, to my old Servant Nelson, who is now one of the Emperor’s domestics, and who is to be baptized at the Roman Catholic Church— The Princess de Tarente is to stand as his Godmother.— I visited Count Stedingk and Baron Blome; neither of whom was at home; and after this the morning walk brought it to 4 O’Clock, before I got home— Mr: Navarro mentioned to me that the house in which we both reside is about to be sold to the Emperor; so that we shall have to find accommodations elsewhere— After dinner I went with Mrs: Adams over to the Apothecary’s island, and looked at a house there which is to be let. We found it difficult as we went to cross the square of St: Isaac, owing to the crowd of People at the Sports and shows, and to the numbers of Carriages moving in the Procession— When we came home just after Sunset the Square was quite empty. Mr: Harris spent most of the Evening with us.

20. At half-past ten this morning I went to the Roman Catholic Church, and saw the Christening of Nelson— The Ceremony was very long, continuing nearly two hours, and was performed partly at the door of the Church; partly in the nave, and partly within the Chancel near the Altar— It included I believe the three Ceremonies, of baptism, confirmation, and Communion. There was a bishop or at least a person with the episcopal mitre, and staff, and ten or twelve other Priests, officiating; with the quire of singers in the organ-loft chanting, the greatest part of the time— There was so much of a crowd that I could neither see nor hear distinctly much of the performance, though it was the first Roman Catholic Baptism that I had seen. As the baptism of a person full grown it differed much from that of an infant— He was first baptized at the door— Then was introduced leaning upon the arm of the Priest, up to the Nave. There was anointed with Oil, and had a white fillet tied round his head, and a white robe over his garments. At the conclusion the Communion was administered to him— It was nearly one O’Clock when I came home, and I then went with Mr: Harris and Mr Gray to the Gatchellis, and Easter-Shows on the St: Isaac’s Square— We took my son Charles with us— I had promised to take him to see these sights, and I anticipated the pleasure of seeing him delighted with them— But the first into which we went proved to be the tight-rope dancers, and he was frightened instead of being pleased— After seeing them four or five minutes, he said he wanted to come away, and I
could not prevail upon him to stay— He was ready to cry, and I took him out from that booth— I attempted to take him into another, but he was so reluctant that I sent Paul home with him— We went into two others of the Booths where we saw the Chinese Shadows, and an exhibition of transparencies similar to those of the last year.— The only novelty of the Chinese Shadows was a Representation of Noah’s Ark, and the flood— As it was cold, and 4. O’Clock was approaching, and especially as I had been disappointed in the expectation of seeing Charles enjoy the sights, I went no farther, but returned home, and at 4. O’Clock went to dine at Mr: Glukoff’s. The Company was not numerous. The two brothers and their wives, their sister, and another young Lady; an old Gentleman whom I had met there before, Captain Thomson, master of the ship Inca, Mr: Woodward, and the Gentlemen of my family were there.— After dinner, and just as I was coming away, Mrs: Glukoff gave me a handsome porcellain Easter-egg for Charles— I walked on the Boulevards, and saw the procession of the Carriages untill Sun-set, immediately after which they dispersed— Mr: Preuss and the Chevalier Krabbe the Secretary of the Danish legation paid us evening visits—

21. As Mr: Preuss intends to depart to-morrow, and I have been so long without an opportunity to forward despatches & letters for America, I was employed almost the whole of the day in preparing for him— Mr: Harris was with me this morning, and mentioned that the Minister of the Finances, Mr Gourieff had appointed him seven O’Clock this Evening— Mr: Woodward was also here this morning and again in the Evening— He is going as far as Liebau with Mr: Preuss, and I gave him a Passport— Mr: Harris came and dined with my family— I took a very short walk before dinner, and returning met the Emperor walking on the Boulevard. There was something of a crowd around and behind him, and he pass’d me without seeing, or at least without looking at me. I dined at Baron Blome’s, with a small company of thirteen persons—four or five of whom I did not know— Generals Pardo, and Watzdorf, and Mr: Lesseps were of the number— General Pardo indulged his national feelings as a Spaniard more freely than usual, and was quite amusing— Count Bose the Secretary of the Saxon Legation was in agony of distress between the desire and the fear of talking politics— Blome and Lesseps were very guarded and reserved— I walked on the Boulevards, and saw the closing scene of the Gachellis— This is the last day of the sports and that when they are most crowded— The swings and whirligigs, were in most active motion untill the Sun was set— I walked untill 9 O’Clock when all was silent, and almost deserted. The Square was entirely clear, and the Guard of Soldiers on the square was dismiss’d— The weather which untill Easter day had been for some time foul, has been the whole eight-days remarkably fine— I have been this day and last Sunday interrupted in my usual Sunday reading, and only finished the first volume of Massillon’s Conferences— It closes with several of his Pastoral letters, or Mandemens—which give me the occasion to some common place reflections— For example in ordering a Te Deum on the birth of the Dauphin, son of Lewis 15. the Bishop, considers it as a special blessing of Providence, to continue in a manner almost miraculous the crown of France in the same race, while other Nations frequently pass’d from one family of Sovereigns to another— Oh! blind to fate— That dauphin was never to wear the crown, and his Son was to be the last king of the Capet line. In all the orders for a Te Deum on account of Victories, he speaks of them as disasters to be deprecated, and only to be celebrated as approximations to peace— These are truly Christian Sentiments, but in the triumphant days of Louis 14. and now in those of Napoleon, a Bishop would hardly be found who would dare in public proclamation to express them— They are the popular Sentiments only of pacific times, and would meet little favour in ages of glory.

22. I made up this day the packets for Mr: Preuss who left the City this afternoon about 5. O’Clock.— Mr: Smith and Mr: Everett dined abroad. In my evening walk I took Charles with me. All the booths in the Square of St: Isaac are demolished, and the sliding hills, whirligigs and Swings are all taken away. Mr: Harris came and shewed me Mr: Gourieff’s official answer to his note: which is that the Emperor has referred it to Baron Campenhausen to report to him upon it, and Mr. Gourieff in the conversation that he had last Evening with Mr: Harris referred him also to Mr: Campenhausen, for a further answer— Mr: Harris having already had with Baron Campenhausen a discussion of some asperity, requested me as by a particular favour to him, to take this matter off his hands by writing to the Baron, which I promised to do if it should be necessary, and in the mean time I determined to ask a verbal conference with him— I therefore wrote and sent him a note requesting it— Long Evening visit from Mr: Bridge.

23. Mr: Montréal called to see me this morning, and said that as the river might soon become impassable he had come to take leave untill the river shall be broken up. I went nevertheless with Mrs: Adams over to the Apothecary’s Island, where we looked over two Country-houses which are to be let— It was between one and two O’Clock when we went over the Bridge, and there was then no appearance of the rivers breaking up—there were however one or two small open passages in the channel of the river, above and below the Bridge— We returned about three O’Clock and the Bridge was already loosened from the abutments on both sides— There was a crowd of People waiting to see the breaking up of the river, and the passage for Carriages over the river was barr’d— We descended from the Carriage and cross’d the Bridge on foot— The bars were opened and our Carriage was allowed to come over after us— Mrs: Adams then returned in it home, and I walked round the Boulevard to the Hermitage Bridge on the Quay, and back, untill five O’Clock, to observe the progress of the Water, encroaching upon the ice, and to see if the Bridge of Boats should be carried away. At five I went home and dined, and about seven in the Evening returned taking Charles with me to walk. I found the Bridge still in the same condition, though carriages were no longer allowed to pass, and the open passages in the Channel above the Bridge were so enlarged that they had almost reached the road from the Palace Corner over to the Island.— That however stood yet firm, entirely across the river— I walked round the Boulevard again and back, untill after Sunset— Just then I met Mr: Harris on the Quay, who thought the Bridge would not go for three or four hours.— Returning I met Mr: Fisher, and went with him to the Bridge. At half-past eight O’Clock, the road started and opening a passage for the current, increased the pressure of the ice upon the boats pushed those at the Channel down and the others obliquely to the boat at the abutment, which it press’d about fifteen feet wide of its wonted place— And thus it remained untill the road itself had floated down to the mass of ice around the boats— Its weight and pressure then parted the floating part of the Bridge entirely from the abutments, and the boats were urged partly by the ice, and partly drawn by cords towards the Island side of the river— Nothing was broken nor was there any apparent violence in the operation. I walked back to the Palace Quay, and found the Channel of the river open all the way along, and up above the Palace. I then returned to where the Bridge had been, and the passage there was not yet entirely free— It was however open below.— There were numbers of People at the Bridge to see its departure, and among them an old man, who said he had lived fifty-five years in this City and never had seen it before— I came home about ten O’Clock— I had sent Charles home before— The weather was fine, but as usual on the breaking up of the river, cold and windy— I found Mr: Harris with the Ladies— Baron Campenhausen paid me a visit while I was from home, upon the Island.

24. While we were at breakfast this morning, about 10 O’Clock, the salute of 5 guns from the fortress announced to us that the passage of the river in boats was again free, and that the Governor had brought the glass of water to the Emperor— I received a note from Baron Campenhausen informing me that he would see me at any hour this morning— I accordingly went about 1. O’Clock to his house, and had a conversation with him— He told me that it had never been his intention that bonds should be required for the production of the Russian Consular Certificates upon the last admitted American Cargoes— That a mere engagement of the Consignees without any penalty was all that he had required, and that was merely to save the appearances in regard to the obligations of this Country— That the custom-houses had misunderstood his instructions, but he had written yesterday a new order to explain his former direction, and had given facilities, to take the engagements of the Consignees immediately here, without requiring any at the out-ports where the vessels are— He said that he had sent to Mr: Gourieff some weeks ago, his protestation against the decision of the Commission at Archangel in the case of the Eliza, and he did not know why Mr: Gourieff had not finished the business in the Counsel— That he had ordered the papers of the American vessel at Abo to be dispatched that she might come to Cronstadt— That in the case of the Venus at Riga, he would give orders that the engagement to produce the papers (from Cadix) should be taken, as in the others, or that the petition of Mr: Kennedy the Super-cargo should be granted—the Cargo sold, and the proceeds deposited untill he shall himself produce the papers.— He believed that he had not one case of an American vessel left upon hand.— As to the time, which had been given for producing the papers, a year and day, that had been fixed on the proposition of Mr: Meyer and Mr: Stieglitz themselves; but if longer time was wanting, he was as willing that they should have two or three years as one— I spoke to him of the Correspondence between the Secretary of State and General Turreau, respecting the french Consular Certificates— He said there was one Hamburg vessel, that had produced a french Certificate of a Consul in America, and they were embarrassed what to do with it, but the most extraordinary case they had was of a house at Rotterdam, which had made a solemn declaration before
the Russian Consul that they had expedited a certain vessel and Cargo, to a Russian commercial house at Archangel, and a declaration equally solemn before the french Authorities, that they never had expedited any such vessel— The Baron as usual talked about commercial politics in general, but in a style a little different from that of his last conversation with me on the same topic.— After leaving him I walked round the Fontanka, and the river Quay home. The river is almost entirely clear of ice— I walked again after dinner— Mr: Harris; Mr: Tilden and Mr: Plummer pass’d the Evening with us— Mr: Harris brought me an invitation to Mr: P. Severin’s; but I sent an excuse— Mrs: Adams was very unwell this Evening, and extremely ill in the Night.

25. Mrs Adams continued so ill that I was up untill past 4 this morning and about 3. with the utmost difficulty roused up the house maid Madelain— From 4 untill 10 I reposed— In the course of the morning I wrote a note to Count Romanzoff, requesting a Courier’s Passport for Mr: Lynch, who goes with Mr: Tilden, next Monday— Mr: Smith dined abroad— I walked on the Quay of the river morning and Evening— I found the front gate of the Summer Garden open. In the Evening I finished reading the first Volume of Tooke’s View of Russia— Read likewise some pages of Carr’s Northern Summer—the french translation lent us by Mr: Moses.

26. I called this morning upon Mr: Navarro, and borrowed of him a copy of the Treaty between Portugal and Russia, of Decr: 1798. He had some news, but of the authenticity of which I have some doubts— Mr: Harris called upon me afterwards, and had the same information. I suppose from the same Source— I walked longer than usual morning and Evening; in the whole not less than eight Miles— In the Evening I read some of the letters of Porter’s travels in Russia; an American edition of which has been lent us by Mr: Patterson— He also called upon me this morning— Porter has more sense, than Carr, and I find in his letters what I have miss’d in all the former writers; some account of the religious ceremonies of the Russians.— Mrs: Adams was better; but still quite unwell.

27. Early visit this morning from Mr: Montréal and Mr: Consolat— I recommended to Mr: Montréal to be prepared for such Events as may ensue— Visit afterwards from Mr: Lynch and Mr: Tilden who still have the intention of going on Monday.— I called to see Count Stedingk to ask him for a Courier’s passport for them to be used in Sweden; but the Count was not at home— Walk round the Quay of the Neva and the Fontanka— Went with the Ladies this Evening to the little Theatre and saw Le Mechant the master-piece of Gresset, and Bruéys et Palaprat a Comedy in one Act by Etienne— I had never seen nor even read the Méchant, though it is one of the most celebrated Comedies of the French Theatre— The character is well delineated and supported; but all the other characters of the piece are sacrificed to it— Cleon, le Méchant who delights in scattering discord wherever he goes, merely for the pleasure of making mischief— He is the bosom-friend and back-biter of every other personage in the play— His only occupation is to set Parents and Children, Brother and Sister, lover and friend at strife with each other— And most of them are his dupes— There is a contrasted character, Ariste who reconciles them all together again, and together with an honest and sagacious Soubrette detects and exposes Cleon— But the scandal of the double-dealer is so keen, and the goodness of Ariste is so cold that the vicious character is by far the most brilliant of the two. The moral is amiable and just— The versification elegant, harmonious and easy. The language and manners decent without exception. But the whole composition deficient in the vis-comica, of Moliere or Regnard.— On returning home I found a Passport for Messrs: Lynch and Tilden, from Count Stedingk, to whom on finding him not at home I had written and asked one.

28. My occasional occupations of this day again encroached upon the employments to which I have destined a part of it— I was engaged in preparing for the departure of Mr: Lynch and Mr. Tilden— I received the Courier’s Passport for them from Count Romanzoff— I walked both morning and evening— Mr: Harris called upon me this morning, as did Mr: Navarro, and in the Evening we had a visit from Mr: Patterson. I read the first Discourse in Massillon’s second Volume of Conferences— It is upon the vocation to the Ecclesiastical state; and so much like one of those in the first volume that it seems merely an abstract from it, or a rough sketch of it— I read also the Sections 11 and 12 of Robinson’s character of Jesus Christ— Catherine pass’d the Evening at Madam Colombi’s.

29. Mr: Lynch and Mr: Tilden called about noon upon me, and took their Passports, and the order for Post-horses— I gave at the same time to Mr: Lynch a letter for Dr: Rush, with the small package, containing the ring, which Count Romanzoff sent me for him, by the order of the Emperor— Mr: Lynch has engaged to deliver it himself to Dr: Rush. About eight this Evening they called again and I delivered to them all my despatches and letters for America, together with the packets sent me to be forwarded by Messrs: Navarro,
Colombi, Montréal and Krehmer, and a packet from Mr: Harris, which he had brought to go by this opportunity. Mr: Harris was here at the same time— I have now dispatched all the letters for America that I have had in preparation— I was all this day writing and making up my packets; excepting the time while taking my morning walk— I commenced this day the week of regimen at the opening of Spring— Mr: Bridge was here the latter part of the Evening— We had cards.

30. Mr Plummer paid me a visit this morning, and Mr: Harris came with Mr: Sheaff, a son of Mr: Jacob Sheaff of Portsmouth— Mr: Plincke our Land lord was also here— I sent to enquire of him whether he was about to sell his house to the Emperor, as I had repeatedly heard— He said that five or six weeks since the Minister of the interior had sent to enquire of him whether he would sell the house, which the Emperor wanted for the use of some public Offices— He had expressed his willingness to sell if he could obtain his price, of which he had sent to the Minister a minute— This price was found too high, and he had been told that a certain sum had been appropriated for the purchase of a house for the object in view, which was not equal to his demand— He had declared that he could not abate from it, and was informed that no additional appropriation could take place without the sanction of the Imperial Council— Since which he had heard nothing further of the matter, and did not expect that any thing further would be done about it.— I therefore concluded to give up the plan of taking a house on the Island for the Summer, and to trust to my lease— I walked morning and Evening— Met General Pardo and walked with him.— Catherine pass’d the day and Evening at Madame Colombi’s— I read several of Porter’s letters.

Day. The General distribution of my daily employments continues the same ever since our residence has been fixed in this house— I rise irregularly between 6 and 9. in the morning, and begin the day by reading five chapters in the Bible— A practice which I have followed for many years, and which brings me through the Book once a year, allowing for an occasional interruption of one day in four— As I have not had any such interruption since the commencement of the last year, I finished the English Bible before the end of September, and began the French Bible as translated by the Pastors and Professors of the Church of Geneva, with the Arguments to the Chapters and Reflections by Ostervald, Pastor of a Church at Neufchatel, and a Preface to the Apocryphal Books, by Mr: Martin— I finished the Old Testament yesterda the 29th of March, and the Apocrypha yesterday— But this Apocrypha contains neither of the two Books of Esdras, which are in the English Bibles. Nor are there any reflections of Ostervald upon the Apocryphal Books— After this morning exercise I usually write my journal of the preceding day— Breakfast from 10 to 11.— Write Letters and pay or receive visits untill 3 or 4. P.M— Walk an hour— Dine at 5. Walk another hour, and close the Evening in conversation, with Company at home, occasional visits abroad, or reading— As the Evenings shorten I have drop’d the custom of writing a page in short-hand which I pursued for about four months— My letters for America engross the largest portion of my time; which I do not yet employ in a manner satisfactory to myself.
